author: fradamt
content: How would it result in lower TPS if > 99% of txs are not affected by it at all? In terms of real use cases (non attacks), the only thing that's made more expensive is basically just rollups switching to calldata, which is not something we want

author: fradamt
content: As for the attack concern, I don't see why it would need a rogue builder, since anyone could just submit very large txs. You have to pay for the basefee of course (as would the builder/proposer anyway), but it's not that expensive to do it for some time. Even if it's  not a huge problem, why would we allow this at all? What's a legitimate  reason to allow blocks that are  20-30x larger than normal?

author: funnygiulio
content: no - it wont because that case is degenerate and should not be allowed

author: funnygiulio
content: we never had a 3.5 MB block and imo this is only going to happen if someone makes a block with the intention of doing so - additionally 3.5 MB is not that bad and the network might actually absorb it
